text: Foreign Nationals Brochure
label: BODY

text: Foreign Nationals
label: HH1

text: Federal Election Commission
label: BODY

text: Published in July 2003
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: HH2

text: The ban on political contributions and
label: BODY

text: expenditures by foreign nationals was first
label: BODY

text: enacted in 1966 as part of the amendments
label: BODY

text: to the Foreign Agents Registration Act
label: BODY

text: (FARA), an “internal security” statute.  The
label: BODY

text: goal of the FARA was to minimize foreign
label: BODY

text: intervention in U.S. elections by establishing
label: BODY

text: a series of limitations on foreign nationals.
label: BODY

text: These included registration requirements for
label: BODY

text: the agents of foreign principals and a
label: BODY

text: general prohibition on political contributions
label: BODY

text: by foreign nationals.  In 1974, the
label: BODY

text: prohibition was incorporated into the
label: BODY

text: Federal Election Campaign Act (the FECA),
label: BODY

text: giving the Federal Election Commission
label: BODY

text: (FEC) jurisdiction over its enforcement and interpretation.
label: BODY

text: This brochure has been developed to help clarify the rules regarding the political
label: BODY

text: activity of foreign nationals; however, it is not intended to provide an exhaustive
label: BODY

text: discussion of the election law.  If you have any questions after reading this, please
label: BODY

text: contact the FEC in Washington, D.C., at 1-800-424-9530 or 202-694-1100.  Members of
label: BODY

text: the press should contact the FEC Press Office at 202-694-1220 or at the toll free number
label: BODY

text: listed above.
label: BODY

text: Except where otherwise noted, all citations refer to the Act and FEC regulations.
label: BODY

text: Advisory Opinions (AOs) issued by the Commission are also cited.
label: BODY

text: The Prohibition
label: HH2

text: The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) prohibits any foreign national from
label: BODY

text: contributing, donating or spending funds in connection with any federal, state, or local
label: BODY

text: election in the United States, either directly or indirectly.  It is also unlawful to help
label: BODY

text: foreign nationals violate that ban or to solicit, receive or accept contributions or donations
label: BODY

text: from them.  Persons who knowingly and willfully engage in these activities may be
label: BODY

text: subject to fines and/or imprisonment.
label: BODY

text: Foreign Nationals Brochure
label: BODY

text: Who is a Foreign National?
label: HH3

text: The following groups and individuals are considered “foreign nationals” and are,
label: BODY

text: therefore, subject to the prohibition:
label: BODY

text: • Foreign governments;
label: BODY

text: • Foreign political parties;
label: BODY

text: • Foreign corporations;
label: BODY

text: • Foreign associations;
label: BODY

text: • Foreign partnerships;
label: BODY

text: • Individuals with foreign citizenship; and
label: BODY

text: • Immigrants who do not have a “green card.”
label: BODY

text: Individuals:  The “Green Card” Exception
label: HH3

text: An immigrant may make a contribution if he or she has a “green card” indicating his
label: BODY

text: or her lawful admittance for permanent residence in the United States.
label: BODY

text: Domestic Subsidiaries and Foreign-Owned Corporations
label: HH2

text: A U.S. subsidiary of a foreign corporation or a U.S. corporation that is owned by
label: BODY

text: foreign nationals may be subject to the prohibition, as discussed below.
label: BODY

text: PAC Contributions for Federal Activity
label: HH3

text: A domestic subsidiary of a foreign corporation may not establish a federal political
label: BODY

text: action committee (PAC) to make federal contributions if:
label: BODY

text: (1) The foreign parent corporation finances the PAC’s establishment, administration,
label: BODY

text: or solicitation costs; or
label: BODY

text: (2) Individual foreign nationals:
label: BODY

text: • Participate in the operation of the PAC;
label: BODY

text: • Serve as officers of the PAC;
label: BODY

text: • Participated in the selection of persons who operate the PAC; or
label: BODY

text: • Make decisions regarding PAC contributions or expenditure.
label: BODY

text: Corporate Contributions for Nonfederal Activity
label: HH3

text: Additionally, a domestic subsidiary of a foreign corporation (or a domestic
label: BODY

text: corporation owned by foreign nationals) may not donate funds or anything of value in
label: BODY

text: connection with state or local elections if:
label: BODY

text: (1) These activities are financed by the foreign parent or owner; or
label: BODY

text: (2) Individual foreign nationals are involved in any way in the making of donations to
label: BODY

text: nonfederal candidates and committees.1
label: BODY

text: 1  This means that foreign nationals may not participate in donation activity, allocate funds for donations,
label: BODY

text: or make decisions regarding donations (e.g., selecting the recipients, approving the making of donations, or
label: BODY

text: approving the issuance of donation checks).
label: BODY

text: Foreign Nationals Brochure
label: BODY

text: Please note that many states place additional restrictions on donations made to
label: BODY

text: nonfederal candidates and committees.  11 CFR 110.20(i).  (See also AOs 1992-16,
label: BODY

text: Volunteer Activity
label: HH2

text: Generally, an individual may volunteer personal
label: BODY

text: services to a federal candidate or federal political
label: BODY

text: committee without making a contribution.  The Act
label: BODY

text: provides this volunteer “exemption” as long as the
label: BODY

text: individual performing the service is not compensated
label: BODY

text: by anyone.  11 CFR 100.74.  The Commission has
label: BODY

text: addressed applicability of this exemption to volunteer
label: BODY

text: activity by a foreign national, as explained below.
label: BODY

text: In Advisory Opinion 1987-25, the Commission
label: BODY

text: allowed a foreign national student to provide
label: BODY

text: uncompensated volunteer services to a Presidential
label: BODY

text: campaign.  By contrast, the decision in AO 1981-51
label: BODY

text: prohibited a foreign national artist from donating his
label: BODY

text: services in connection with fundraising for a Senate
label: BODY

text: campaign.2
label: BODY

text: Nonelection Activity by Foreign Nationals
label: HH2

text: Despite the general prohibition on foreign national contributions and donations,
label: BODY

text: foreign nationals may lawfully engage in political activity that is not connected with any
label: BODY

text: election to political office at the federal, state, or local levels.  The FEC has clarified such
label: BODY

text: activity with respect to individuals’ activities.
label: BODY

text: In Advisory Opinion 1989-32, the Commission concluded that although foreign
label: BODY

text: nationals could make disbursements solely to influence ballot issues, a foreign national
label: BODY

text: could not contribute to a ballot committee that had coordinated its efforts with a
label: BODY

text: nonfederal candidate’s re-election campaign.
label: BODY

text: In Advisory Opinion 1984-41, the Commission allowed a foreign national to
label: BODY

text: underwrite the broadcast of apolitical ads that attempted to expose the alleged political
label: BODY

text: bias of the media.  The Commission found that these ads were not election influencing
label: BODY

text: because they did not mention candidates, political offices, political parties, incumbent
label: BODY

text: federal officeholders or any past or future election.3
label: BODY

text: 2  The Commission has stated that this opinion is not superceded by AO 1987-25.  Individuals may obtain
label: BODY

text: further guidance in this area by requesting an advisory opinion about their proposed activity.
label: BODY

text: 3  Individuals and committees should consider requesting an advisory opinion before engaging in other
label: BODY

text: types of political activity involving foreign nationals.
label: BODY

text: Foreign Nationals Brochure
label: BODY

text: Assisting Foreign National Contributions or Donations
label: HH2

text: Under Commission regulations  it is unlawful to knowingly provide substantial
label: BODY

text: assistance to foreign nationals making contributions or donations in connection with any
label: BODY

text: U.S. election.  11 CFR 110.20(h).  “Substantial assistance” refers to active involvement
label: BODY

text: in the solicitation, making, receipt or acceptance of a foreign national contribution or
label: BODY

text: donation with the intent of facilitating the successful completion of the transaction.  This
label: BODY

text: prohibition includes, but is not limited to individuals who act as conduits or
label: BODY

text: intermediaries.  67 FR 69945-6 (November 19, 2002).
label: BODY

text: Soliciting, Accepting, or Receiving Contributions and
label: HH2

text: Donations from Foreign Nationals
label: HH3

text: As noted earlier, the Act prohibits knowingly soliciting, accepting or receiving
label: BODY

text: contributions or donations from foreign nationals.  In this context, “knowingly” means
label: BODY

text: that a person:
label: BODY

text: • Has actual knowledge that the funds solicited, accepted, or received are from a
label: BODY

text: foreign national;
label: BODY

text: • Is aware of facts that would lead a reasonable person to believe that the funds
label: BODY

text: solicited, accepted, or received are likely to be from a foreign national;
label: BODY

text: • Is aware of facts that would lead a reasonable person to inquire whether the
label: BODY

text: source of the funds solicited, accepted or received is a foreign national.
label: BODY

text: Pertinent facts that may lead to inquiry by
label: BODY

text: the recipient include, but are not limited to the
label: BODY

text: following: A donor or contributor uses a foreign
label: BODY

text: passport, provides a foreign address, makes a
label: BODY

text: contribution from a foreign bank, or resides
label: BODY

text: abroad.  Obtaining a copy of a current and valid
label: BODY

text: U.S. passport would satisfy the duty to inquire
label: BODY

text: whether the funds solicited, accepted, or
label: BODY

text: received are from a foreign national.
label: BODY

text: Monitoring Prohibited Contributions
label: HH2

text: When a federal political committee (a committee active in federal elections) receives
label: BODY

text: a contribution it believes may be from a foreign national, it must:
label: BODY

text: • Return the contribution to the donor without depositing it; or
label: BODY

text: • Deposit the contribution and take steps to determine its legality, as described
label: BODY

text: below.
label: BODY

text: Either action must be taken within 10 days of the treasurer’s receipt.
label: BODY

text: Foreign Nationals Brochure
label: BODY

text: If the committee decides to deposit the contribution, the treasurer must make sure that
label: BODY

text: the funds are not spent because they may have to be refunded.  Additionally, he or she
label: BODY

text: must maintain a written record explaining why the contribution may be prohibited.4
label: BODY

text: 11 CFR 103.3 (b)(4) and (5).  The legality of the contribution must be confirmed within
label: BODY

text: 30 days of the treasurer’s receipt, or the committee must issue a refund.5
label: BODY

text: If the committee deposits a contribution that appears to be legal, but later discovers
label: BODY

text: that the deposited contribution is from a foreign national, it must refund the contribution
label: BODY

text: within 30 days of making the discovery.  If a committee lacks sufficient funds to make a
label: BODY

text: refund when a prohibited contribution is discovered, it must use the next funds it
label: BODY

text: receives.  11 CFR 103.3 (b) (1) and (2).
label: BODY

text: 4 This information must be included when the receipt of the contribution is reported.
label: BODY

text: 5 For example, evidence of legality includes a written statement from the contributor explaining why the
label: BODY

text: contribution is legal (e.g. donor has a green card), or an oral explanation that is recorded in memorandum.
label: BODY
